transcript:
Patient: One situation that stands out is when I was preparing a report for my boss. I spent hours making sure every detail was perfect, but when I submitted it, I couldn't stop thinking about how I could have done better.

Therapist: That's a great example, Amir. Let's use this situation to practice the thought record technique we've been working on. Can you walk me through the different columns of the thought record, starting with the situation or trigger?

Patient: The situation was submitting the report to my boss. The emotions I felt were anxiety and inadequacy, both at around an 8 out of 10 intensity.

Therapist: Good. What automatic thoughts came up for you in that situation?

Patient: My main automatic thought was, "The report isn't good enough, and my boss will think I'm incompetent."

Therapist: Okay, let's look at the evidence for and against that thought. What evidence do you have that supports the idea that the report wasn't good enough and that your boss will think you're incompetent?

Patient: Well, I know I could have included more data and analyzed it in more depth. And my boss has high standards, so I assume he'll be critical of any shortcomings.

Therapist: And what evidence do you have against that thought?

Patient: I guess the fact that I did submit the report on time and that it contained all the essential information. And like I mentioned earlier, my boss has complimented my work in the past.

Therapist: Great. Now, let's generate an alternative thought based on the evidence. What's a more balanced way of looking at the situation?

Patient: An alternative thought could be, "I submitted a comprehensive report on time, and while there's always room for improvement, it's unlikely that my boss will think I'm incompetent based on one report."

Therapist: That's a fantastic alternative thought, Amir. It acknowledges the effort you put in and the reality that perfection is unrealistic, while also recognizing that your boss's opinion of you isn't solely determined by one piece of work. How do you feel when you consider this alternative thought?

Patient: When I think about it that way, my anxiety and inadequacy feel less intense, maybe around a 4 out of 10.

Therapist: That's a significant shift, Amir. This is a great example of how challenging our automatic thoughts and considering the evidence can help us arrive at more balanced and helpful perspectives. I encourage you to continue practicing this technique whenever you notice similar thoughts coming up, both at work and in other areas of your life.

Patient: I will. It's helpful to see how breaking down my thoughts and examining the evidence can change how I feel.

Therapist: Absolutely. As we continue to practice this skill, it will become more natural and automatic. Remember, the goal isn't to get rid of negative thoughts entirely, but rather to develop the ability to catch them, examine them, and respond to them in a more helpful way.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess I've been expecting myself to be able to stop having negative thoughts altogether, but I can see how that's unrealistic.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Amir. The expectation that we should be able to control or eliminate our thoughts is actually another form of perfectionism. Instead, we're working on changing our relationship with our thoughts and learning to respond to them in a more adaptive way.

Patient: I'm starting to see how perfectionism has been influencing my thoughts and behaviors in so many areas of my life.

Therapist: That's a really important realization, Amir. As we continue to explore and challenge these patterns of perfectionism, you'll likely find that it becomes easier to catch and reframe these thoughts. And as you do that, you may notice changes in your emotions and behaviors as well.

Patient: I'm looking forward to seeing those changes. It's been tough, but I feel like I'm starting to make progress.

Therapist: I'm really glad to hear that, Amir. Remember that progress isn't always linear, and there will be ups and downs along the way. But every time you practice these skills, you're taking a step in the right direction.
